div.l: And hath I lost þe gryndyng of þe whete
And paied for þe soper eủery dele
Of Aleyn and of Iohan þat bette hym welle
His wyf is swyued and his doughter als
Lo swiche it is a · Meller to be fals
And þ̉er þ̉er fore þis prouerbe is saide ful sothe
Hym thar not wene welle þat Euyl doth
A gylour shal hym self by giled be
And god þat sitteth high in magiste
Saue alle þis companye grete and smale
Thus haue I quyte þe Miller in my tale
Here endith þᵉ Reves tale

and here
by gynnyth þe prolog of þᵉ Cookes tale
The coke of london while þᵉ Reue spake
For Ioy hym þought he clowed hym on þe bake
Ha · ha qduod he for cristes passion
This Miller hath a · sharp conclusion
Vppon his argument of herbigage
Wel seide salamon in his langage
Ne bryng not eủery man in to þyn hous
For herberwyng be nyght is ꝑperlous
Wel oughte a · man auysed for to be
Whom þat he brought in to his pⁱriuyte
I pray to god so ȝeue me sorow ⁊and kare
If euer sithen I hight hogge of ware
Herd I a Miller better y sette a werke
He hadde a · Iape of malice in þe derke
And therfore if ȝe vouchesaf to here
But god for bede þat we stynt here
A tale of me þat am a · pore man
I wil ȝow telle as wel as eủer I can
A · litul Iape þat fel in oure Cite
Oure oost vnswarid and said I gᵃrante it þe
Now telle on Roger loke þat it be gode
For mony a pastay hast þow let blode
And mony a Iacke of douer hast þow sold
That hath I ben twyes hoot ⁊and twyes cold
Of mony a pilgrym hast þow cristes cors
For of þi persely ȝet þei fare þe wors
